Debates in DH Digital Project Index
Mina Rees Library / CUNY Graduate Center
About

Back to the Future, DH Edition

By Patricia Belen

2011 was the inaugural year for the Debates in the Digital Humanities book series (edited by Matthew K. Gold). As expected, much of the first book’s contents revolve around the origins and definitions of the term “digital humanities” which wasn’t a new term. As Matthew Kirschenbaum points out in “Chapter 1: What Is Digital Humanities and What’s It Doing in English Departments?”, during the previous decades scholars had already published well-documented articles on “humanities computing”, an antecedent of DH. Considering the indisputable connections between computers, technology, and digital humanities, this blog post will delve into the past, to the years 2010–2011, and rediscover key moments in computing history. What technological advancements were happening twelve years ago, when the contributors for Debates in the Digital Humanities were compiling this first volume?

Voyeurism for Everyone

Text analysis gains momentum with the creation of Voyeur, a web-based text analysis environment, created by Stéfan Sinclair and Geoffrey Rockwell, through their collaborative project Hermeneuti.ca. In 2010, Voyeur began appearing in citations, syllabi, coursework, research and conferences. Sinclair and Rockwell popularized the tool more by giving workshops and tutorials. Because the tool was freely available to anyone with an internet connection, any researcher or student could experiment with text analysis. Today, the spirit of Voyeur lives on in Voyant, its popular successor and essential tool for DH work.

The Passing of a Pioneer

“Humanities computing”, along with personal computing, might look very different today without the contributions of Steve Jobs who passed away on October 5, 2011. Apple.com’s reaction was to replace its entire homepage with a black and white portrait of Jobs. Clicking on the photo led to this statement: “Apple has lost a visionary and creative genius, and the world has lost an amazing human being. Those of us who have been fortunate enough to know and work with Steve have lost a dear friend and inspiring mentor. Steve leaves behind a company that only he could have built, and his spirit will forever be the foundation of Apple.”

Social Media Can’t be Stopped

In his article, Kirschenbaum describes how integral Twitter is to DH and scholarly communication. This is only one of the many ways Twitter and other social networks were (and still are) used. 2011 brought us Occupy Wall Street, a protest against economic equality that occurred both in person in Zuccotti Park, NYC and online through social media, namely with #OccupyWallSt. OWS itself was inspired by Arab Spring protests which also used social media effectively. And as for Twitter’s main competition, they weren’t exactly quiet at this time. Facebook was the most visited website of 2010, Mark Zuckerberg was Time Magazine’s Person of the Year (2010), and The Social Network film was released (2010).

Streams and Clouds

In 2010, Netflix announced they would be transitioning to a streaming-only plan for $7.99 a month (instead of sending DVDs by mail), believing that streaming media services will be driving businesses in the future. In 2011, Spotify launched in the U.S. for similar reasons. And at the same time, we realize our smartphones and tablets don’t have the capacity to hold all of our digital life anymore so more services move to the cloud - which prompts Google users to search for “what is the cloud”?

Tablets and Kindles

The fact that I am reading Debates in the Digital Humanities from 2011 through Manifold, and not as a printed publication is related to the history of the tablet as a personal computing device. The first ipad was released in 2010. It was designed to read, play games, browse the internet and social media and more, all through apps downloaded through a digital store. Amazon’s reading device, Kindle, was already on the market by this time. And although the debate of whether print is dead lives on, there is no doubt that the innovations in digital publishing are attributable to tablets and kindles.
